intro: Patagonula tweedyana, commonly known as the Tweedy's Patagonula, is a rare flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of its family. It thrives in high-altitude, rocky habitats and is adapted to the cool, humid climates of its native range. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
